awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CISE-ANR: CNS Core: Small: Modeling Modern Network Traffic: From Data Representation to Automated Machine Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
To successfully maintain and secure communications networks, operators need to monitor their behavior and investigate security, performance, and other problems as they arise. Recent advances in network protocols and applications present fundamental challenges for monitoring network traffic. Specifically, Internet traffic, from web traffic to Domain Name System (DNS) queries and responses, is becoming ubiquitously encrypted, obfuscating information that might otherwise be available for these tasks.  Additionally, network traffic is increasing in volume and rate, precluding detailed logging and analyzing individual packets or streams. Finally, the Internet is becoming more centralized, and many services have also become cloud-based, making it more difficult to identify applications or services according to fixed identifiers such as IP addresses and port numbers.  Answering even basic questions about Internet traffic has thus become increasingly challenging. 

This project seeks to develop techniques to regain visibility and insights into modern network traffic considering these trends.  We address three research questions towards regaining visibility into modern network traffic. First, this project will study how to represent traffic data in ways that are amenable to modeling, and that could optimize models for both supervised and unsupervised modeling tasks. We will explore the impact of representations across four dimensions: (1) timeseries representations; (2) representations across flows; (3) representations at higher layers; and (4) operations on compressed data.  Second, we will build on our work on traffic data representation to develop a set of tools to automatically explore model and traffic representations tailored for network traffic problems. Towards this goal, we will build a large-scale repository of labeled flows across several different applications and services as well as evaluate data representations that will be used to build statistical learning models about network traffic. Finally, we will use the software platforms and algorithms we build to design new techniques and tools for operators to solve the challenges that prevent them from transferring developed models from laboratory experiments to real-world deployments. We will extend automated model selection to account for systems costs and real-world limitations; address the need to be able to determine when models become inaccurate and to distinguish model inaccuracies from problems that are inherent to the network; and improve model robustness by investigating general approaches for model transfer. 
   
All software we create in this project will be publicly available and open source. Additionally, we plan to integrate the software systems into tutorials for the community, undergraduate and graduate courses, and outreach and education programs in the community, in collaboration with partners such as the University of Chicago's Office of Special Programs and Office of Civic Engagement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The Internet and the individual networks that compose it serve a critical role in today's economy and society. To successfully maintain and secure these networks, operators need to monitor their behavior as well as quickly investigate new problems as they arise. However, recent network and protocol advances pose fundamental challenges to monitoring networks: (1) traffic is becoming ubiquitously encrypted preventing direct access to quality of service indicators; (2) networks have grown orders of magnitude faster precluding detailed logging and analyzing individual packets or streams; (3) the Internet itself has evolved to become more centralized, preventing IP addresses from identifying services. This award supported building and releasing several new systems and machine learning (ML) approaches for understanding and protecting modern networks. 

We built and released Retina, an open source Rust-based software framework that enables both network operators and researchers to analyze reassembled network flows and application sessions on modern networks running at over 100gbE. Contrasting many prior works in the space, Retina enables asking arbitrarily complex analysis questions about traffic and directly running machine learning models against modern network traffic in real time. Retina is available under the Apache 2.0 license at https://github.com/stanford-esrg/retina.

While many prior works have proposed machine learning models, many have struggled to be productionized on real-world networks, because of their systems performance characteristics. We introduced CATO, a framework that simultaneously optimizes both ML model performance and systems performance on real-world networks. By automatically building and evaluating real-world ML pipelines, CATO ensures that proposed models are practically deployable. Further, CATO can provide up to 3600 times lower inference latency and 3.7 times higher zero-loss throughput while simultaneously achieving better model performance. In addition, CATO extended Retina to support a "menu" of derived traffic characteristics that can automatically be optimized over by future works rather than requiring developers to manually come up with and test one-off traffic characteristics.

On very high-bandwidth networks, flows can still arrive faster than model inference rates. In partnership with the University of Chicago, we helped to develop ServeFlow, a novel "fast-slow" model architecture for networking ML pipelines where a tiered, increasingly expensive machine learning models are used as needed for classifying traffic, reducing median latency by 40.5x while maintaining similar accuracy. Last, we introduced Clid, a supervised supervised modeling approach for clustering network handshakes when identifying about the client or server isn't included in the handshake. 

The project's findings were disseminated through peer-reviewed publications at top-tier venues in networking, including at ACM SIGCOMM, USENIX Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI), Free and Open Communications on the Internet (FOCI). This project supported multiple Ph.D. students in computer networking, as well as three undergraduate and M.S. students, who went on to pursue Ph.D.s in networking and security as a result of the project.


Last Modified: 03/09/2025
Modified by: Zakir Durumeric
